Hermeneutic Marginalization

The manticore as a beast of burden

Published

Dec 2025

Two kinds of representation

There are two kinds of beasts representing evil in medieval beastiaries; those that deceive and those that cause fear and death (Piñero Moral 2021). These two characterizations are used by artistic means for educating the illiterate populations of the Middle Ages. More specifically, the purpose of this education is for orthodoxy, it is intended to promote proper behavior and right action.

In her book Epistemic Injustice, Fricker (2007) defines hermeneutic injustice as a gap in collective interpretive resources that hinders a person’s ability to make sense of their own experiences. This is more akin to the kind of evil that deceives. There is good reason to think that hermeneutic injustice is not solely a modern evil, that if Fricker is correct, then there would be motivation to restrict a group’s hermeneutic participation in social life.

Historically, this injustice was committed against women, but there is not much reason to think that it was committed only against women. As an injustice, this is a source of evil in that it is an experience that is direct an intuitive by the victim of the evil (Russell 2016, 1). More specifically, it is a representation of the one kind of evil. This is the kind of evil that is evil specifically because it deceives. This kind of evil was represented artistically in medieval beastiaries through the image of the manticore.

Hermeneutic Marginalization

“Beastiaries are composed of different hermeneutic codes which are mapped to different sensitive levels, that is, from the level describing mere anatomy we may turn to the one dealing with ethical-philosophical consideration; and further turn to the one on moral perspectives which are later complemented with the theological ones (Voisenet 2020, pp. 321–25). In all these cases, the fields of word and those of image are intertwined (Kay 2017). In the end, XII–XIII century bestiaries, books on natural history and encyclopedias allow us to access a world where both the creative power of goodness and evil are present: The excellence of divine creation and the subtlety of diabolic action play a role.”

Types of hermeneutic codes

  • ‘Mere’ anatomy
  • Ethical-philosophical considerations
  • Moral perspectives
  • Theological perspectives

What is a hermeneutic code in these cases?

A way to understand this may be arts divergent foci on simple reality and complex reality. Between these two representations is a set of norms culturally and socially constructed to guide the representation of the human condition: experience, knowledge, and beliefs. The conflict here is between God and the devil. What specifically are the adverse actions, carried out by the one against the other in this space? Jesus’ death, burial, and resurrection is at one level an adverse action carried out by the work of the devil, yet at the same time, it is also symbolic of the ultimate victory, that of God over sin, death, hell, and the grave.

“Its commitment with reality is undeniable yet the reality which it at tempts to represent is so complex and vast that the limits between what is and what is not, between what we believe and what we know, between what we are and what we wish to be, are often blurred (Cronin 1941). Medieval ars is much more than a set of norms which ought to be followed to produce something that can be called art.”

“Art, so understood, is a necessary element in the configuration of human condition in terms of experience, knowledge, and beliefs. It is within this context where the action of God and that of the devil provide one of the most profound lectures of reality.”

References

Fricker, Miranda. 2007. Epistemic Injustice: Power and the Ethics of Knowing. Oxford ; New York: Oxford University Press.
Piñero Moral, Ricardo. 2021. “Aesthetics of Evil in Middle Ages: Beasts as Symbol of the Devil.” Religions 12 (957, 11). https://doi.org/10.3390/rel12110957.
Russell, Jeffrey Burton. 2016. The Prince of Darkness: Radical Evil and the Power of Good in History. Ithaca: Cornell University Press.
